climbs.name: Wren's Nest
climbs.fa: Craig Fry and Alan Roberts, April 1985

content.description: A strenuous step-up near the start takes you to a knobby face.  The steep wall above has good holds and nice moves, but somewhat questionnable rock.  Vogel's guidebook lists this as a toprope, but it is adequately protected as a lead.
content.location: This is on Wane's Wall, a north-facing wall in a narrow corridor near the summit of the rock.  Wren's Nest is to the right of a "human mold" hueco.

climbs.name: Under A Raging Moon
climbs.fa: Roger Linfield and Dennis Yates, Dec. 1986

content.description: Jam up a very flared crack, using some stems on the main wall, and reach a great hand and fist crack that leads to the top.
content.location: Starting from a large platform above Garden Path and Chute To Kill, this is an obvious flared crack in a right-facing corner.

climbs.name: Too Thin For Poodles
climbs.fa: Roger Linfield and Dennis Yates, Dec. 1986

content.description: Climb up to the fork in the crack (crux).  Take the left fork and climb (5.10A) up to a great stance on a huge knob.  Clip the first bolt and then face climb up and left (5.10A) to a second bolt.  Continue to the top.  The face was full of thin, loose flakes on the first ascent, but it should get better with use.
content.protection: mostly thin gear plus two bolts
content.location: From the right end of the south face (Chute To Kill area), walk around right for another 50 yards.  This route starts at an obvious thin crack, which forks part way up.

content.description: Scramble up easy rock with minimal pro to a ledge and then contiue up the face past a bolt to anchors on top.
content.location:
Down and right of

Slow Mutants

in the middle of the crag.

climbs.name: Slow Mutants
climbs.fa: Don Wilson, Karen Wilson & Jack Marshall, February 1990

content.description:
This route is located on the speckled face right of

Muffin Bandits

and shares a common start with that route.

Begin on

Muffin Bandits

and then cut right onto the tan and brown patina face passing a curving horizontal crack where a fixed pin used to exist (a small cam works well). Continue onto the upper face passing four bolts and some loose holds with one hard sequence (5.11a) before topping out. Gear belay and walk off/scramble down the backside.

climbs.name: Science Experiments You Can Eat
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon, Cyndie Bransford and Steve Orr, March 1995

content.description: Easier climbing past horizontals and discontinuous cracks lead to a thin face section with two bolts.
content.location:
Just left of

Muffin Bandits

on the blunt arÃªte.

climbs.name: Pillar Of Dawn
climbs.fa: Roger Linfield and Dennis Yates, Dec. 1986

content.description: This is an o.k. route up to a great summit.  A shallow dihedral splits the south face.  Follow the dihedral up to a fork.  Take the right fork, around a roof, and to the top.
content.protection: mostly small gear; bolted belay/rappel anchor on top
content.location: Several hundred feet around to the right from other climbs on the south face is a large pillar.  This route climbs the south face.

climbs.name: Muffin Head
climbs.fa: Dave Evans, AJ Burch , Kia Ravenfar 2/05

content.description:
Start by coming in from the left. Climb horizontal face holds just right of a crack to a ledgy area. Walk right 15' on a sloping ledge. Climb up and right placing pro in a horizontal and then higher in a straight up thin crack. Step right and tiptoe up to a knob (5.10b/c). It is possible to sling the knob for pro. Mantle onto a ledge and walk right to the dihedral of Muffin Bandits.

These features can be seen in Bartlett's Wonderland Guide just to the right of the L that marks where Science Experiments You Can Eat starts.

The most striking route on the middle section of The Techulator is the hanging dihedral of Muffin Bandits. Apparently the first ascent party climbed directly into the dihedral via the thin crack which is the lower continuation of the crack which comes down out of the dihedral. This start may be a bit loose. Climb the dihedral via an interesting combination of finger jamming, stemming and face holds. It is also possible to climb into the dihedral from horizontals to a knob just below the left end of a ledge which is at the bottom of the dihedral (5.10b?).

climbs.name: High and Dry (AKA Short But Flared)
climbs.fa: Alan Roberts and Bill Meyers, April 1985

content.description: Climb the obvious crack.  A thin finger crack is in the back of a very flared hand crack.  Despite the flare, it protects well with cams.
content.location: This route is on a prominent boulder located high up on the summit area.  A prominent flared crack splits the south wall of this boulder.

climbs.name: Garden Path
climbs.fa: Roger Linfield and Dennis Yates, Mar. 1987

content.description: Climb the crack and gully, with just one hard move.  On the first ascent, tree branches, a chockstone, and some loose rocks detracted from our experience.
content.protection: standard rack, plus maybe a nut tool to do a little gardening
content.location: This is well right of the center of the south face, in a crack/gully left of Chute To Kill.

climbs.name: Friendly Fists
climbs.fa: Roger Linfield and Dennis Yates, Dec. 1986

content.description: Climb the crack, which is easier than it looks, due to some good face holds.  This climb is in the shade almost all day.
content.protection: mainly hand and fist size gear
content.location: This is an overhanging fist crack in a left-arching crack, on the northeast size of the Techulator.

content.description: Varied climb up a corner, over a steep bit to a face, then a crack finish to the top. Â Fun!
content.location:
Right facing corner just left of a small tree bush.

Near dead center down low on the south face of the Techulator.

climbs.name: Chute To Kill
climbs.fa: Dennis Yates and Roger Linfield, March, 1987

content.description: Moderate liebacking leads to the top of a flake; the first bolt is a bit higher.  The crux is above the second bolt.
content.location: This is near the right end of the south face.  It follows a broad, very shallow waterchute.
